awd_titl_txt: Scholarship Program for Mathematics and Sciences Study
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at Albertus Magnus College in New Haven, Connecticut will provide scholarships for talented, low-income students with demonstrated financial need who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in biology, chemistry, or mathematics. In addition to scholarships, the program will provide academic and other support to increase the persistence of academically talented, low-income students.  The project design includes a comprehensive program that incorporates critically influential aspects of student success: a strong academic curriculum, financial support, a wide array of student support services, and career planning. Additionally, a system of individual supports is provided by faculty and peer mentors to augment the institutional offerings. Scholarships and support for academically strong students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic vitality of the greater New Haven region and the nation.

The program organization is informed by research indicating that a significant reason for STEM attrition is poor classroom experiences of students. In addition to student support activities, the project will study the impact of a professional learning community of STEM faculty on persistence and retention. Select faculty at Albertus will participate in a collaborative faculty development program. The process will involve groups of faculty developing lessons, teaching these lessons while their colleagues and knowledgeable others observe, engaging in post-lesson discussions to reflect on how to improve the lesson, and finally revising and re-teaching the lessons. The project will study how a professional learning community approach in higher education can lead to improved retention and degree completion in STEM fields. The program expects to help talented, low-income students to complete bachelor's degrees and contribute to the growing bioscience industry in the region. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community and help increase understanding of the attributes and practices of successful student scholarship and support programs.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the Albertus Magnus College (AMC) Scholarship Program for Mathematics and Sciences Study (S-STEM) project is to increase the capacity of the College to provide financial, academic, and peer support for STEM majors who will pursue careers or advanced studies in STEM-related fields.

Three objectives to achieve this goal: (1) enroll and retain a total of 15 scholars, who are in financial need and demonstrate strong or promising academic skills in the study of biology, chemistry, and mathematics; (2) provide curricular and co-curricular programs that support a students? attainment of a higher education degree in a STEM discipline; and (3) promote early career exploration and facilitate networking opportunities for S-STEM scholars to attain their post-graduate goals.  Project Outcomes are listed below.

Year One: 1) The Founder and President of Aria Management Consulting, LLC, a bioscience management agency, and a strategist for the Economic Development Corporation of New Haven, CT. discussed education and advisement on closing the gender gap in leadership; 2) The Director of the Yale Center for Genome Analysis  and the Keck Biotechnology Resource Laboratory, spoke on next-generation DNA sequencing and protein analysis techniques, and provide guidance on careers in biotechnology and graduate education in the biosciences; 3) The PI designed a three-day molecular biology workshop for high school students held in July of 2017 at Albertus Magnus College.  Students, representing five local area high schools, conducted laboratory experiments and computer-based activities to analyze the gene controlling bitter taste. 

Year Two: 1) Two STEM luncheons were held during the 2017-2018 academic year ? one in the fall and one in the spring semester. S-STEM scholars were introduced to students and faculty in the Department of Biology, Chemistry, and Mathematics at the fall semester luncheon.  Students had the opportunity to voice suggestions for growth and improvement of curricular and co-curricular activities in the department.  These events also stimulated peer support and a strong sense of community across the different STEM disciplines; 2) Four of the five current S-STEM scholars had the opportunity to attend various meetings and conferences during the spring semester.  The PI brought an S-STEM scholar and two other biology majors to a regional networking meeting of Project Kaleidoscope (PKAL, a branch of the Association of American Colleges & Universities dedicated to reforming higher education in STEM).  Several scholars attended the Biomedical Sciences Careers Student Conference in Boston, Massachusetts.  One scholar accompanied chemistry professor Isaac Hon in April of 2018 to the New Haven Third Annual Student Research Symposium, sponsored by a local section of the American Chemical Society.  Two other S-STEM scholars joined the Co-PI (professor of mathematics) in attending the Harold L. Dorwart Lecture ?Mathematical Modeling in Cancer Research? at Trinity College. 

Year Three: 1) The S-STEM scholars participated in a ?Summer Institute? in August, living in a residence hall the week prior to the start of the 2018-2019 academic year. The institute was designed to continue fostering a strong learning community and peer support among the group of scholars; 2) Students, accompanied by the PI and other co-investigators, visited the Coast Guard Research and Development Center in New London, CT., and to Sema4, a local biotechnology company that produces genetic testing tools and conducts research in the fields of genomics and data science.   Other field trips included a presentation on the University of Bridgeport?s Health Sciences Program, tours of the cadaver lab and clinics (acupuncture, chiropractic, and naturopathic medicine) along with lunch with Health Sciences deans and directors; 3)  Dr. Loel Tronsky, co-PI, moderated a pilot application of the Japanese Lesson Study with STEM faculty and S-STEM scholars. This teaching method uses a multi-disciplinary laboratory experiment created by the STEM faculty; 4) Three speakers participated in the STEM Seminar Series over the course of the academic year. These included topics covering the BioScience EcoSystem in Connecticut, an info session on pursuing a career in dentistry and establishing a private practice, and a presentation on using human stem cells to model neurodegenerative diseases.

Year Four: A research collaboration was developed with Arvinas, Inc., a biopharmaceutical company in New Haven, CT. that has developed a protein degradation technology to treat cancer.  In direct partnership with Dr. Kevin Coleman, Vice President of Exploratory Biology at Arvinas, S-STEM scholars will have the option of participating in a research project to corroborate Dr. Coleman?s recent findings on the positive effect of a small molecule drug in treating estrogen receptor positive human breast cancer.  The research was conducted at Albertus, with participating students receiving course credit for their work.  

These outcomes along with several others, supported the goals outlined earlier and provided AMC the opportunity to apply for and attain funding to support future STEM scholars.
